comments:
When running against a 3.2.2 target platform the data binding libraries can't load AbstractTableViewer.  AbstractTableViewer is not a part of 3.2.2 and we don't reference it from our code from what I can tell.  When just building against a 3.2.2 platform the tests run fine.  It's only when running against the built plugins does this issue occur.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Download a 3.2.2 Eclipse SDK.
2. Download the latest 3.3 I build.
3. Place org.eclipse.core.databinding, org.eclipse.core.databinding.beans, and org.eclipse.jface.databinding from the I build in the 3.2.2 plugin directory.
4. Check out org.eclipse.jface.examples.databinding and org.eclipse.jface.tests.databinding into a new workspace.
5. Set the target platform to the 3.2.2 SDK.
5. Run the data binding tests.

Looking at the generated bytecode, it seems nearly impossible to achieve binary downwards compatibility.  What looks like a call to TableViewer.insert() in the source code gets compiled like this:

invokevirtual org.eclipse.jface.viewers.AbstractTableViewer.insert(java.lang.Object, int) : void 

JFace introduced a new abstract class AbstractTableViewer in 3.3 that did not exist in 3.2.  There is nothing we can do about this in client plug-ins, the only possible fixes for this would be to either (1) add methods in TableViewer that call the super method, or (2) always compile the data binding plug-in against the 3.2 version of JFace.

The second stack trace is caused by a similar problem - in 3.3, a new abstract class BaseLabelProvider was introduced.  ObservableMapLabelProvider inherits from LabelProvider, which inherits from BaseLabelProvider.  ObservableMapLabelProvider.dispose() calls super.dispose(), and this call is translated into the following since LabelProvider does not override dispose():

invokespecial org.eclipse.jface.viewers.BaseLabelProvider.dispose() : void

Adding JohnA and Pascal to the cc list - it seems that our versioning story is more complex than we (at least I) thought: A plug-in that would work in 3.2 stops working for 3.2 when it is recompiled against 3.3.  This would mean that plug-ins that claim to work with (say) JFace 3.2 should be compiled against that version of JFace in our builds, not against the current version. Or perhaps the answer is to always require at least the current version of other bundles?

This is a very interesting case, and it reinforces my belief that the only way to be sure about our lower version bound is to always compile against the lower bound version of a bundle's prerequisites. Some work is needed in our build infrastructure to be able to make this happen.
Changing OS from Mac OS to Mac OS X as per bug 185991
